hivewrongseason: Hive will not swarm until Spring.
blockhelp-claypothive-empty-notop:
Pick ceramic brood pot up in empty bag slot,
use populated skep, or hive top.
blockhelp-claypothive-populated-notop:
Pick up ceramic brood pot in empty bag slot,
or place hive top.
blockhelp-claypothive-empty-withtop: Right click removes honey pot, or use populated skep.
blockhelp-claypothive-populated-withtop: Right click removes honey pot, wax ring indicates harvestable.
fromgoldencombsguide-text:
"How doth the little busy bee
Improve each shining hour
and gather honey all the day
From every opening flower!"
 - Isaac Watts

Advanced Apiary 101 - From Golden Combs
The bee is domesticated but not tamed - William Longgood



Getting Started
To start on your new apiary adventure, you first must acquire clay, either fire clay or blue clay will do. This clay is used to make a brood pot, and a honey pot. After firing your ceramic hive parts, pick it up in a backpack slot and place it in a place with plenty of flowers.


Populating Your Hive
Your next step is to find a wild hive with a standard skep. Once you have a populated skep, simply place it in the hive base by clicking right clicking the ceramic brood pot with it. Set your empty and fired honey pot on top of your new hive by right-clicking, and wait.

Harvesting Your Hive
When you see a wax ring around the top of the hive, it's time to collect your harvest! Just pick up the honey pot again, set it on the ground, and clean it out with a knife. Now take the empty honey pot and put it back on the hive base.

Growing Your Apiary
Be warned, ceramic hives may be reusable, but they won't swarm to new hives. You'll have to fill new skeps to make new ceramic hives."



Advanced Apiary 102 - Langstroth Hives

The Langstroth Hive takes a significant amount of work to get into operation, but once you do, you'll never want for honey or wax again. Getting your new hive going requires linen, a copious amount of wax, and plenty of boards.

You'll start by building a base for your hive. Next you'll need a super and a brood box. You can make the brood box by placing a brood top on a super by right-clicking it with it. Make sure they're made of the same materials!

You'll also want to have a frame rack to line and maintain your bee frames.. Bee frames are made with resin, boards and sticks. They then need to be placed in the frame rack and lined by right-clicking them with a Frame Liner before being placed in the super.

Start Keepin' Them Bees!
Now that you have all the parts you'll need, it's time to get you some bees! As with the ceramic hive, you'll need to get yourself a skep with a bee colony in it. Place them in the brood box in the same manner and you have an active brood box!

Just one step left. You need to build a hive! Start by placing the base, and placing up to 4 supers on it with up to 10 lined frames inside. Then top it off with a Brood Box holding an active hive!

You're now in business! The hive will report how many harvestable frames it has in it when you look at it. The hive fills from the top down, and is capable of holding up to 40 frames by default! Take note, if you have a large hive inside, it will fill up to two frames in the same time that a skep will fill once. Each frame returns approximately the same as a skep does.

Harvesting And Maintaining Your Frames
Once you have harvestable frames, you'll need to place them in the frame rack, and use a knife to get the comb off. Doing this will slightly damage the frame, and your knife. When your frame breaks, you'll get an empty frame back, which you can refill with a waxed linen frame liner. You can also repair it before it breaks by using waxed flax twine on it while it's in a frame rack.
item-handbooktext-langstrothbroodtop: Use this to create a brood box by right-clicking a super with the same wood pattern.
item-handbooktext-langstrothside: A component used in making supers, bases, and broodtops in Langstroth Hives.
item-handbooktext-emptybeeframe: The foundation that your bees will build their comb on. It's not ready yet though! You need to place it in a frame rack and then right-click it with a Frame Liner to create a lined frame.
item-handbooktext-linedbeeframe: This is a frame ready to be placed into a super for your bees to build comb on. When it's ready to be harvested you just take it out, place it in a frame rack and right-click it with a knife to collect honeycomb. This will also damage the frame. You can repair it using waxed flax twine in a frame rack. If you allow it to break completely, it will become an empty frame. You can then reline it with a Frame Liner.
item-handbooktext-harvestablebeeframe: This frame is ready to harvest! Just place it in a frame rack and scrape off the honey with a knife to get honeycomb. You'll damage the frame a little doing it, but they can be repaired with waxed flax twine in a frame rack. If the frame breaks, you can replace the frame Liner.
item-handbooktext-frameliner: Frame liners are created using waxed linen, and a knife. They are then used to line empty frames in a frame rack.
